body:
### Summary

Please just remove:

```yaml
   vars:
       myvarnames: "{{ q('varnames', '^my') }}"
       mydict: "{{ dict(myvarnames | zip(q('vars', *myvarnames))) }}"
```
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/complex_data_manipulation.html#id15

No tests exist for this and a simple copy paste is producing some sort of DoS-crash.

There is no additional reference where this was ever used or tested.

Original:
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/46979/files#diff-0b3f5962e2d097f45656021c9579639763d56e82a67bd97d37694027e2f686d9R205-R213

with _debug.yml_:
```yaml
- become: no

  gather_facts: no

```

body:
This file is required to be able to upload a collection

It is present in
https://github.com/ansible-collections/collection_template/blob/main/meta/runtime.yml
but that does not get used by default.

Without this, if you use the "ansible-galaxy collection init" command
and you try and publish that collection without adding this file, you
get the error:

"ERROR! Galaxy import process failed: 'requires_ansible' in
meta/runtime.yml is mandatory, but no meta/runtime.yml found (Code:
UNKNOWN)"

##### SUMMARY
<!--- Describe the change below, including rationale and design decisions -->
add file to collection skeleton that is needed for uploading

<!--- HINT: Include "Fixes #nnn" if you are fixing an existing issue -->

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest -->
- Bugfix Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Write the short name of the module, plugin, task or feature below -->
ansible-galaxy

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
<!--- Include additional information to help people understand the change here -->
<!--- A step-by-step reproduction of the problem is helpful if there is no related issue -->
This file is present in this other collection skeleton repo, but didn't get added here to this skeleton which is what is actually used by the command afaik.

It would be nice to be able to backport this.
I'm not super opininonated on the ansible version, just that it should be one in which collections are supported -- I just copied what is in this other repo's meta/runtime.yml https://github.com/ansible-collections/collection_template/blob/main/meta/runtime.yml

title: Jinja2 3.1 Breaks filter

labels.name: needs_info
labels.description: This issue requires further information. Please answer any outstanding questions.

labels.name: test
labels.description: This PR relates to tests.

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a bug.

body:
### Summary

Version 3.1 of Jinja2 removed deprecated code, including `environmentfilter`: https://github.com/pallets/jinja/pull/1544

Attempting to execute Ansible operations that use `filter` with Jinja2 >= 3.1 results in:

```
[WARNING]: Skipping plugin (/opt/python3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible/plugins/filter/core.py) as it seems to be invalid: cannot import name 'environmentfilter' from 'jinja2.filters'  (/opt/python3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/jinja2/filters.py)
```

This issue appears to have been originally addressed here: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/74667

### Issue Type

Bug Report

### Component Name

filter

### Ansible Version

```console
$ ansible --version
ansible [core 2.12.3]
  config file = None
  configured module search path = ['/home/jenkins/.ansible/plugins/modules', '/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /opt/python3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible
  ansible collection location = /home/jenkins/.ansible/collections:/usr/share/ansible/collections
  executable location = /usr/local/bin/ansible
  python version = 3.10.4 (main, Mar 24 2022, 16:14:08) [GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-44)]
  jinja version = 3.1.1
  libyaml = False
```


### Configuration

```console
$ ansible-config dump --only-changed
<no output>
```


### OS / Environment

Linux (EL7)
Python 3.10.4 compiled from source
Jinja2 3.1.1
Ansible 5.5.0 (according to `pip3 freeze`)
Ansible Core 2.12.3 (according to `pip3 freeze`)

Same results with Ansible 2.10.7 and Ansible Base 2.10.9 using Python 3.9.10.

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--- Paste example playbooks or commands between quotes below -->
Install Jinja2 version 3.1.x
Execute playbook

### Expected Results

No Python import error

### Actual Results

```console
[WARNING]: Skipping plugin (/opt/python3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible/plugins/filter/core.py) as it seems to be invalid: cannot import name 'environmentfilter' from 'jinja2.filters'  (/opt/python3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/jinja2/filters.py)
```

title: Allow to configure the ciphersuite for SSL context

labels.name: waiting_on_contributor
labels.description: This would be accepted but there are no plans to actively work on it.

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: feature
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a feature request.

body:
### Summary

Python 3.10 changed the default set of supported ciphers: https://docs.python.org/3/library/ssl.html#ssl.SSLContext / https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/e91b0a7139d4a4cbd2351ccb5cd021a100cf42d2/Modules/_ssl.c#L170

When the client ansible tries to connect to a client which does not support any of these ciphers the handshake will fail with the following exchange:
* Ansible ---- Client Hello ------> Client
* Client ------ Handshake Failure -----> Ansible

In Python SSL library, it is possible to modify the list of usable ciphers using the `set_ciphers` command. However currently ansible (via the usage of httpapi connectors) does not allow to modify the list of the ciphersuite and so the default Python ones are being used.

(Note that there does not seem to be a workaround to modify the default list of cipher leveraging environment variables.)

This idea is to add the possibility to pass some string to the `urls.py` code to be able to set the allowed ciphers and overwrite the python default if need be.

Note: this is indeed asking to use "considered-less-secure" ciphers but can be useful in some cases / with some legacy devices when using Python 3.10 and above.

### Issue Type

Feature Idea

### Component Name

module_utils/url.py

### Additional Information

Testing against my current device using Python 3.10 - modifying the current code at:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/module_utils/urls.py#L1419

```python
          if HAS_SSLCONTEXT and not validate_certs:
              # In 2.7.9, the default context validates certificates
              context = SSLContext(ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv23)
              if ssl.OP_NO_SSLv2:
                  context.options |= ssl.OP_NO_SSLv2
              context.options |= ssl.OP_NO_SSLv3
              context.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
              context.check_hostname = False
[...]
```

With

```python
          if HAS_SSLCONTEXT and not validate_certs:
              # In 2.7.9, the default context validates certificates
              context = SSLContext(ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv23)
              if ssl.OP_NO_SSLv2:
                  context.options |= ssl.OP_NO_SSLv2
              context.options |= ssl.OP_NO_SSLv3
              context.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
              context.check_hostname = False
              # Allow all ciphers rather than only Python 3.10 default
              context.set_ciphers("DEFAULT")
```

Allows me to avoid the SSL Handshake issue


### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow the Ansible Code of Conduct

body:
Ideally the page should enumerate all characters whose presence requires the value to be quoted (I'm guessing that includes quotes and possibly backslashes?).

Also: maybe you can also escape whitespace with a backslash, not just quote it?

##### SUMMARY
<!--- Describe the change below, including rationale and design decisions -->
The page said "When declared inline with the host, INI values are interpreted as Python literal structures (strings, numbers, tuples, lists, dicts, booleans, None). Host lines accept multiple key=value parameters per line. Therefore they need a way to indicate that a space is part of a value rather than a separator." but failed to say what that way was. I added quoting as one possible way.
<!--- HINT: Include "Fixes #nnn" if you are fixing an existing issue -->

body:
### Summary

A user created with no password stays locked, even if explicitely set as unlocked.

### Issue Type

Bug Report

### Component Name

ansible.builtin.user

### Ansible Version

```console
$ ansible --version
ansible [core 2.11.6] 
  config file = /usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = ['/home/gerrit/.ansible/plugins/modules', '/usr/local/share/py38-ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/ansible
  ansible collection location = /home/gerrit/.ansible/collections:/usr/local/share/py38-ansible/collections
  executable location = /usr/local/bin/ansible
  python version = 3.8.9 (default, Jun 12 2021, 01:09:04) [Clang 10.0.1 (git@github.com:llvm/llvm-project.git llvmorg-10.0.1-0-gef32c611a
  jinja version = 3.0.1
  libyaml = True
```


### Configuration

```console
$ ansible-config dump --only-changed
CACHE_PLUGIN(/usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg) = jsonfile
CACHE_PLUGIN_CONNECTION(/usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg) = /tmp/facts_cache
CACHE_PLUGIN_TIMEOUT(/usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg) = 7200
DEFAULT_GATHERING(/usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg) = smart
DEFAULT_HOST_LIST(/usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg) = ['/home/gerrit/ansible/hosts']
DEFAULT_VAULT_PASSWORD_FILE(/usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg) = /home/gerrit/.ansible/vault>
INTERPRETER_PYTHON(/usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg) = auto_legacy_silent
PARAMIKO_HOST_KEY_AUTO_ADD(/usr/home/gerrit/git/ansible/ansible.cfg) = True
```


### OS / Environment

FreeBSD 12.3 (running ansible) Debian 11 (being configured).

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--- Paste example playbooks or commands between quotes below -->
```yaml (paste below)
- name: add user
  user:
  name: testing
    password_lock: false
    password_expire_max: 0
```


### Expected Results

I expect an usable (not locked) user being created with no password (`NP`) being set.

```
root@~# passwd -S testing
testing NP 03/28/2022 0 99999 7 -1
```

### Actual Results

```console
The documentation on `password_lock` says `This must be set to False in
order to unlock a currently locked password`. However, even after running
this again, I still get a locked user account (is this a bug, or do I
misinterpret the documentation?).


root@~# passwd -S testing
testing L 03/28/2022 0 99999 7 -1
```

The correct setting (as reported above) can be achieved by running

```
root@~# passwd -d testing
passwd: password expiry information changed.
```


In my option, ansible's user module should already do this. It also doesn't help to explicitely give `password: ""` as user option, the result stays the same (user locked).
```


### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow the Ansible Code of Conduct

body:
### Summary

There exists functionality that allows for the setting of yum configuration options like `tsflags` or `reposdir` realtime when running yum/dnf and this functionality would promote the use of the module for use cases like that.

### Issue Type

Feature Idea

### Component Name

yum/dnf

### Additional Information


```
yum install -y --setopt=tsflags=nocrypto mypackage 
```
vs the preferred way in the added feature
```
name: Install mypackage
yum:
  name: mypackage
  state: installed
  setopt:
  - tsflags=nocrypto
```
